title: Assuming a zombie apocalypse was possible, what aspects of the Walking Dead TV universe seem to be the most inaccurate? - Quora

response.answer_text: Plenty, I’ll go with my ‘short’ list, otherwise you will be here all day reading about things the show gets very, very wrong. ( Ps, I love zombie fiction, and TWD franchise is an example of a well thought out, well funded project and I am not disparaging them ). Fuel. We are at season 10 now of TWD at least, and so far, you can apparently still find abandoned cars pulled over that have good gas in them. Sure, every once in a while you will see a character with a 1G gas can go through the motions like they are accomplishing something long term with 1g of gas. Lets talk gas age… and it DOES age. My lawnmower doesn’t even like to run on last seasons gas. How is that every car they choose starts and runs fine on YEARS old gas? Batteries. Ok, so we have a group of magic cars that will run on years old gas.. I guess they might as well run with years old batteries too. My diesel pickup truck eats 2 high capacity batteries every 3 years. Sure, I can usually push it to 3.5 but it always happens.. I will start it to drive to work one day, and then 8 hours later, they will be dead as a doornail.. the magic timer ran out. I know on a less taxed starting system you might eek out a little more, but lets face it.. a week before the zombie apocalypse started in the walking dead, the entire US population did not go run out and replace all their car batteries so that all vehicles now had a 3–5 year lifespan possibility. There would be a natural mix of old and new, and the older ones should way outnumber the new ones, and the older ones should all be dead by now. Lets also talk about charge state. A battery that stays discharged for a long period of time has a greater chance of going bad. Ever see a dead battery freeze? they will.. it ruins them. Most cars since about the 80’s have some electrical circuits that run continuously. Small modules, the clock, radio memory, etc. it’s not a big draw.. but if the car runs out f gas and is left on the roadside for 5 years.. the battery is far past dead. Some older cars do not have times lighting, so if you leave the door open, the dome light burns.. until the battery dies. THE SHOW HAS CONSTANTLY DEPICTED PEOPLE FINDING CARS THAT STILL HAD ENOUGH JUICE TO TURN OVER years INTO THE SHOW. Sure, as with the 1g gas can above, we have actually seen at least once, someone carrying a battery to put into a car to get it started. So there.. they get 1 instance for free.. the other 99% are not really believable. RE-Chargeable batteries, While I am ranting on batteries, we might as well include the rechargeable types. Since we know that there are limited ways to make power like magic cars that start on magic gas and magic batteries, you can then use car chargers or inverters to make power, there is solar power, and then there are generators that also run on magic gas and may even start on magic batteries. OK.. so there are small pockets of power, but… those rechargeable batteries do not have an infinite life. They have a set number of charges they will take, and depending on the battery chemistry, that charge life decreases with each use. Many rechargeables that have stayed in a discharged state for as little as a year will not charge up. Everyone in these movies are using hand held radios that are using rechargeable batteries. Man they got lucky finding that magic shipment of radios that all had new batteries and that have no problem charging after setting 5 years dead.. etc. What a coincidence right? Especially when they pick up random radios and they are all on the same channel or band. Starting those vehicles. Ok.. so if you run out of gas and leave your car in the zombie apocalypse, do you leave the key in the ignition? Do you put it in the ash tray or under the visor, or do you take it with you thinking that you may come back with a magic 1g gas can? The show is split about 50–50 on this one.. or maybe it’s better to say 40–40–10. About 40% of the time the key is in the car, about 10% of the time the key is nearby, like in a locked office or on a belt of a zombie, and the other 40 % of the time, the characters are hotwiring cars. I think this one burns me the most. Someone leans into drivers floorboard, reaches up grabs a wiring harness yanks it down hard, chooses any two wires, bares them with no tools, flicks them together while someone plays the sound of a car starter bumping, then they just twist them together, the starter starts the car ( on the magic gas with the magic battery ), and now the starter magically stops when the car starts even though the 2 wires are still twisted together. All this happens in about 10 seconds. The hero’s then shift into gear and drive off. Pretty much 100% of what is depicted is 100% wrong. Lets start with the basics. Most vehicles have a steering wheel lock when no key is present. Yes, there are at least 2 easy ways to defeat this that both require tools and at least SOME time and you break 1 of 2 items, and then you can use the steering wheel. No I won’t mention the what or how as this is not a tutorial on stealing cars. Next, the wiring. Have you seen how many wires there are under the dash of a car, and how they are mostly ran in looms, and with most cars being different, the odds that you will blindly reach up and grab 2 of the 3 ( yes, you really need 3* ) wires you need and snatch them down is ..well.. just not possible. Now here is were it gets even more complicated. Back before the mid 70’s, cars were MUCH easier to hotwire! Cars had points ignitions, not electronic computer controlled ignition. You could actually locate a hot 12v wire ( or 6v for them types of cars ), and then locate 2 more important wires. The wire to the ignition coil, and the wire to the starter solenoid You would connect the power wire to the ignition coil wire and twist together. Your Ignition was now ready. You would then brush the starter solenoid wire across that other pair and get the starter turning over. when she started, you let that starter solenoid wire hang loose, it did not get twisted into the bunch, otherwise the starter would continue to grind! That worked great till by about 1974, most vehicles had went to computerized ignitions, and while you could still hotwire, it became more tricky than the 3 finger salute. You still had to deal with the steering wheel lock, etc. Fast forward and you have these vehicles with operator presence systems, like those key fobs or keys with an RFID chip in them. These types of computer controlled vehicles are even HARDER to start! Yet the show depicts hotwiring vehicles all the time in 10 seconds. And before the other engineers ( yes, I am an engineer ), and mechanics chime in about what I left out on the hotwiring, remember.. I am glossing over some details because this is not a tutorial on how to steal a car. - But this one burns me the most I think… Firearms. This one is not endemic to zombie apocalypse fiction , pretty much 99% of movie media depicts using a firearm incorrectly. Racking a slide each scene even though the gun was not shown to have ran out of ammo or had a magazine change. The Stealth rack, where the slide is pulled back quietly and pushed forward quietly so as to not alert the badguy around the corner. The machine guns that go click click click after running out of ammo, or any of the self loading hammerless or stricker guns that click endlessly after running out of ammo, and not having their slide reset. Every hollywood set that depicts firearms use should have to have a firearms instructor on set to show the movie people how a firearm REALLY functions. That’s my short list..

Assuming a zombie apocalypse was possible, what aspects of the Walking Dead TV universe seem to most inaccurate? Thanks for the 2A2. So let's begin…  The Walkers themselves for start are the most inaccurate and unrealistic part of a zombie apocalypse. Not because they are reanimated corpses but because of how they are depicted.    Their bodies are barely holding themselves together. And still they have enough strength to “wrestle” a human or a horse down, and kill them. I actually saw in TWD a Walker, walking and leaving most of his flesh behind. Like… How did he moved from that point on? Seeing he didn't had the muscle tissue to even keep himself standing up, less alone move. Even their teeth should rot and fall off eventually. Also it's clear they don't really need the flesh they eat. Still they go about eating living things just because. Any virus that created something zombie like, should be like the Clickers in The Last of Us.    Where we see that the bodies of the Infected, are actually changed by the virus. Thus explaining why they keep on going for so long.  The virus! That's the next nonsense thing. We know it is a virus because Edwin Jenner, scientist of the CDC, told us so in Season 1. Now, it would make sense that as animals began to feed on the Walkers that can't even move, would eventually also get infected. Virus do mutate, and jump from species to species. More so if the animal feeds on an infected corpse. So we should be seeing zombie birds, dogs, and all sorts of animals that were also zombified. Another incredibly stupid scene, was when we see that the pigs the Kingdom was supplying the Saviors, were fed with Walker meat. Thus the Saviors that ate that meat, should've all turned into zombies. But it was as if the virus once it enters another lifeform, it ceases to exist.  People! Okay, I get it that as the outbreak begins people are caught unaware and unprepared. But years into a zombie apocalypse, and you still see people making the most absurd mistakes. Also funny enough humans are many times worse than the zombies. In a world filled with zombies, we still see people bickering over the most absurd things. Like who serves who. Who owns what. What land belongs to whom. Humans should be hardcore hardened zombie killing machines. But most are just average zombie killers. And some are even pathetic zombie killers. Even seeing some people are overweight. I got no problem with people that have some more meat in their bones. But in a post apocalyptic world, and you still find overweight survivors. Reminds me of Hugo Hurley in the TV show Lost.  This dude didn't got one bit slimmer in the entire show. When they were for a good time on an island, with very limited resources. It is small things like this, that are very hard to believe. Or even accept. In TWD we are still finding survivors in a physical condition, they shouldn't be. I am about 1.83 meters tall or 6′0″ and I weigh around 97 Kg or 213 lbs. I work out, and I got little fat on my body. BUT… In a post apocalyptic world my physical shape would obviously change. If I couldn't find enough food I would become skinnier. And even if I found enough food, I would know that I couldn't simply eat it all up, expecting to find more food later on. So I would need to conserve food, so I could replenish my energy when I needed to.  Fuel. Funny enough only Fear TWD tackled that issue. Fuel can only “sit” on a car between 12–15 months, until it starts to go bad and becomes useless. But years into the zombie apocalypse you still see people finding fuel in cars, and it still works.  Parts! Have you noticed that they always find what they need lying around. Electronic components like capacitors never degrade and keep on working. So if you find a piece of tech, funny enough it will most likely work. Even though most should not work. There is a reason why we keep electronic devices plugged in and on standby. Most current capacitors have a “lifespan” of over 10,000 hours. Meaning they last more than 416 days, if the equipment being or not being, plugged in. But years into the zombie apocalypse and the tech they find, for the most part still works. Also you don't see them building metallurgical or electronic components, workshops. Things simply keep on working forever, apparently.  The living dead! As you know every person is already infected. Meaning that all it takes to mess up a settlement, is someone dying during their sleep or something like that. They would die and they would come back as Walkers. People know they are infected or at least they should know. Meaning there should be rules for even when someone goes to sleep. And people walking in into someone's home. Still you see that none of that is a problem. People never suddenly die in TWD and start to mess up everyone near them, that haven't noticed the new zombie walking towards them. Also no one so far has even attempted to study the virus, or find a vaccine even if they couldn't find a permanent cure. None but the CDC guy that simply gave up. If a vaccine was discovered then bites would not be a death sentence, like it has been with so many characters. Remember Carl…?  A vaccine would've saved him. Even if not cured him for good.  EDIT: The brain! (Can't believe I forgot about that) So that is also another nonsense seen in TWD. No matter how little the damage done to the brain, the Walker simply goes down for good. Now. If I had to guess I would say the virus is mainly focused on the brain and then perhaps it roots out to other parts of the body, like the teeth. Meaning that it should take almost the complete destruction of the brain to actually stop a walker, and not using some small knife or a stick. The Walkers is TWD by standard already have little of body left. We have even seen Walkers almost entirely burned to a crisp and they still keep on moving, or trying at least. When the very heat of being burned should kill anything, even anything in the brain. Once burned there should be no virus left in the body to move anything.  Laurence Fegan brought up an excellent point that needs to be added to this answer. Who is cutting the grass?? Honestly. You see grass and it's trimmed. Who is this unknown group of survivors of the apocalypse which only goal is to cut grass? Either that or we got some zombie rabbits or locusts that we haven't seen so far lol  And this is basically it. There are many more things, but these are the ones that I find the most unreal to see in the show.

To me the most implausible and inaccurate aspects of The Walking Dead Universe are threefold: First and foremost. The amount of diversity and complete lack of racial animas. Almost every relationship on the show - if not gay - is interracial. Even the villains seem to value diversity. The Governor was a veritable Kumbaya Fest with a Hispanic second in command and a Black third in command. Neegan had a black woman among his “wives” and was trying to recruit Sasha into a leadership role at Sanctuary. Even the damn cannibals were integrated. This show is set in the South - first Atlanta, then rural Georgia, and then finally rural Virginia. However, not a Bubba, Buford, or Cletus has been found! In reality, Tyreese would have been in more danger from the rednecks in the woods than from the walkers. He was walking down those train tracks with two little blond white girls. Green Mile / John Coffee anyone??? I live in the South and I have no doubt that if a zombie apocalypse broke out, it would be “open season” and if minorities weren’t killed outright on sight lets just say the 13th Amendment would be instantly repealed. I see it at the gun range - people using Obama Zombie targets, Travon Martin targets, etc. When a hurricane is coming my neighbors can barely contain their glee at the prospect of maybe getting to shoot “looters”. The reality would be defacto racial segregation - where groups form and people stick with their race much like on a prison yard. The second issue I have is this “plot device scarcity”. It is completely manufactured for dramatic purposes. In reality - there would be plenty of ammunition, fuel, and canned food available. Remember over 99% of the population was dead before Rick woke up, so even if they looted and cleaned out the shelves, they didnt get to consume it, so its still sitting there for the taking. The show is just not looking in the right places. Yes the gasoline would become unstable, but diesel would be fine. So get yourself a diesel vehicle - i dont care what anything from a D-8 Cat bulldozer or farm tractor to a Mercedes luxury car. Remember they are on sale at 100% off. In terms of fuel - theres millions of gallons of diesel in tanks at mines, construction sites, stores, highway departments, refineries, tank farms. But were not done yet. Diesels will run on Jet A which is just really clean kerosene, millions of gallons of which are in tanks at airports. A Boeing 737 has between 4700 and 6800 gallon tanks. Of course you can easily make bio-diesel from just about any lipid, including melted zombie fat if you had to. The reality of the fuel situation is such that they should be running generators and have electrified fences and 24 hour flood lights for decades. With regard to gas - run the cars on ethanol, or propane, or heres an idea - REFINE YOUR OWN GAS! Its really not that hard - its fractional distillation we have been doing it since the 1850s. It wont meet Federal EPA standards but they are shambling around eating brains. As for ammo and weapons again no problem. There are US Military bases all over. The army was out in the streets there is everything from M-16s to Mortars laying around. If you want to go to a base there will be howitzers, tanks, helicopters, hell depending on the base you may be able to help yourself to nukes. No shortage of ammo in 9mm, 223, 308 or 50BMG. Just about every other home in the south has a gun and ammo in it, in most cases several. I got a chuckle out of Eugenes “ammo factory” Half the garages in my subdivision have reloading presses bolted to the workbench. It is a VERY popular hobby. I personally have shotshell reloaders in 12, 16, and 20 gauge, a progressive reloading machine that will do 1500 rounds per hour, and a regular single die station press. This is NOT “rare” hard to find equipment. The single station one was like $140 for the complete set brand new, and the progressive I bought from a guy at the gun range for $400. Shot shell reloaders run $60 - $250 new . Considering a box of dove loads is $8 and a box of steel shot duck loads is $20 - $25 it only makes sense to buy a reloader. Of course - if we completely suspend disbelief a moment and say “powder isnt available” well then how about muzzle loaders or calibers that were originally black powder like 30–30 Winchester? You can get black powder by pissing on hay. Literally. The civil war was fought by scraping dried bat piss from cave walls. Remember, this is 9th century Chinese technology… Finally - and this is a two parter - the selection of leadership and the empowerment of women. Look at TWD… Michonne runs Alexandria and Maggie / Tara run hilltop. Alpha runs the whisperers etc. Give me a break. Wont happen. There will be a mass “return to traditional gender roles”. This is the freaking Zombie apocalypse, its not like they can call the cops, report you to HR, or tweet #MeToo. A post apocalyptic scenario would be a testosterone fueled sausage fest where guys tried to out do each other in “mine is bigger than yours” pissing contests to establish who the alpha dog in the pack was. Sexual violence would be rampant and so common it could be considered “the norm”. A lot of the people who would survive and even thrive in apocalyptic conditions would not be your most “enlightened social justice warrior types”. They would not be welcoming of female leadership. Look at the survivalist camp over on Fear The Walking Dead. This is a militia group of paranoid peppers who are right wing religious fundamentalists and within days of her arrival they accepted Madison as their leader, enacted gun control, and handed their camp over to the native peoples? Give me a break. Yeah that would happen, right wing militia types would jump right on that bandwagon without hesitation. OH YES, WISE LIBERAL FEMALE FROM CALIFORNIA WITH YOUR TEACHERS UNION CARD, WE PROSTRATE OURSELVES BEFORE YOUR LEADERSHIP AND SHALL DISARM AND OBEY AT ONCE. REPARATIONS TO THE INDIGENOUS PEOPLES SHALL BEGIN IMMEDIATELY. PERHAPS YOUR GRACE CAN REGALE US WITH TALES OF THE GREAT NANCY PELOSI??? Now Alicia is the leader over on Fear. You have a California girl who isnt old enough to buy a beer yet (remember she was still in HS when the apocalypse broke out) roaming around Texas. Yet, people follow her including a Texas police officer, a Salvadoran military intelligence officer / torturer, and a registered nurse. Over on the main show, you had Sgt Abraham Ford, an NCO in the Army Rangers placing himself under the command of a small town sheriffs deputy, some random black chick with a sword, and his long haired kid. The Ranger motto is Rangers Lead The Way, not “Rangers Follow Roscoe P Coltrain”. I wont even address the Shakespeares spewing king, cause thats just like WTF who even took that dude seriously for a minute??? The only leadership that is plausible is the villains - the Governor and Neegan. They show the ruthlessness, and skullduggery that would be necessary to seize and hold power. Rick would have been fragged in his sleep long ago and Michonne and Maggie would be chained to a bed in the enlisted mans barracks as a perk for highest daily body count. Harsh but thats reality.

Nobody has ever used a GPS receiver in The Walking Dead. I asked how long GPS, GLONASS, and Beidou navigation systems would remain active in a SHTF scenario like a zombie apocalypse. Nobody who answered had any idea. Do the satellites even need periodic adjustments transmitted from the surface? Maybe the newer ‘birds’ are self maintaining with their software settings? I’d expect perhaps at least a couple of years of useful GPS, if the satellites need periodic updating from ground stations. Many of the earliest GPS satellites from the 90’s are still up there and functional. GLONASS (Russian) and Beidou (Chinese) satellites are mostly newer than America’s GPS satellites. GPS also includes some WAAS satellites in synchronous orbit. There’s also fixed location Differential GPS ground based transmitters. A typical standalone GPS receiver can lock onto up to 12 satellites. The newest can use all three of the systems (USA, Russian, and Chinese) along with WAAS and differential. Ones from a few years ago can use them all except Beidou because China hadn’t begun launches of their satellites yet. In a SHTF situation, differential GPS transmitters would quit, but that’s no big deal because the receivers are made to work with what they can receive. Locking onto as few as three satellites gets latitude, longitude and velocity. Lock onto 4 satellites and the receiver knows its altitude. Cell phones would die along with the power to their networks. While most phones these days have GPS receivers capable of working standalone, they also use A-GPS. A for Assisted. Since the locations of cell towers are precisely known the phone uses various methods of finding its distance from towers it has within range. A sort of differential GPS. Google Maps and other apps don’t keep all the map data on the phone like standalone GPS receivers. There are Android and iOS map apps that do have the ability to have local copies of complete maps for large parts of the planet, but you’re looking at 4 gigabytes for just the continental USA map. So when the power grid goes down, toss the cellphone in a drawer ’cause it’s not gonna work no more for any software that requires access to the phone network or the internet. Trivia bit, the first Savior base Rick and company hits after first going to Hilltop is an abandoned AT&T Satellite Relay Station, now owned by Georgia Tech and being refitted as a radio telescope, named the Woodbury Experiment Station due to its proximity to the real Woodbury Georgia. Senoia (pronounced Seh-NOY, not Sen-oi-ah) Georgia played the part of Woodbury and several other locations. Alexandria, Hilltop and various other locations are pretty close to Senoia. But perhaps The Walking Dead universe *doesn’t have* satellite navigation, like it has no history of voodoo “zombies” and all the fiction that inspired? *whew* Next thing. The walls of Alexandria. What sort of dummy, when faced with a threat that needs walls to keep out, puts the bracing to hold said walls upright on the *outside* of the walls? Since they didn’t bother to clear all trees, buildings, debris etc at least several yards back from the walls, invaders could sneak up with a long chain or strong rope, wrap it around a couple of the supports then hook up a truck in the forest and *yoink* down a big piece of the wall. To keep the bad things *outside* the wall should be braced from the *inside*. But perhaps that came from the silly political thinking of the ex-government leaders of Alexandria and their feelings that having people walking around armed inside the walls was more of a danger than what was outside the walls? Having the braces inside would look ugly and give people bad feelings about not being safe because the heavy bracing would imply *danger*. That’s the thinking that allowed the ‘wolves’ bunch to stab and hack many people to death when they got over the walls - and the lack of creating a proper clear fire zone allowed them to get over the walls. Look up “Idiot Ball” on TV Tropes. That’s when a character does something terribly stupid despite all the experience and evidence around them that doing what they’re going to do would be the worst thing possible. Deanna and Reg were introduced “holding” Idiot Balls. After their failure to do anything about the wife beating doctor got Reg killed, Deanna still held firmly to her Idiot Ball. She only dropped it after the wolves got over the walls and hacked a bunch of people to death. *Then* she really listened to Rick and the rest of his group about how really dangerous things had become in the world outside their walls.

Population density - I get it to some extent, if suddenly 1/2 to 3/4 of the population died and then started trying to eat people, that’s 300–450 zombies per square mile of the metropolitan area I live in. But where would the bodies be? Around hospitals surely, around churches, but in a big outbreak people would die in their own homes. TWD shows huge herds of zombies and also has them dispersed across the countryside. You can’t have both. A big factor on that would be zombies “eating” people. If too much is eaten when the body becomes a zombie it isn’t much of a threat, so there’s a point of saturation in the size of a herd where it won’t really get bigger coming across small numbers of folks. Another thing is by not healing eventually a herd would become a crippled mass just by tripping over curbs or each other and breaking bones. We the living do it all the time even with sentient coordination. Supplies - applying the same “this or that, not both” logic is the problem of supply. If the outbreak happened quickly then there are a lot of people who aren’t using supplies. If it happened slowly our response would be better. There’s a balance to be struck, and TWD shows the outbreak gets really bad really quickly. That means that initially finding supplies isn’t that difficult and still viable for some time. The military - I kind of get this, it wouldn’t do to have a highly armed and organized group of people who are really, really good at breaking things and killing people. Where’s the drama in that? But to discount all of our ability in the face of a zombie epidemic is insulting. Don’t think explosives “kill the brain” as an effective weapon? The concussive force of the blast begs to differ because, you know, that’s where the word for a form of traumatic brain injury - concussion - comes from. TBI from explosives is one of the greatest threats to our military. Think automatic weapons are useless? Yeah, a 50 BMG at waist level will smash bones through several layers of zombies and leave you with a lot of crippled bodies. People are very inventive in killing things, and having an easily distracted dumb predator would be devastated by anyone with access to military equipment and knowledge. They finally did it to some extent in World War Z - blast the loudspeakers in a stadium and drop a bomb in the middle - goodbye horde.  But really you could do that on any scale. Fly helicopters with blasting music low and slow to draw the herd out of the city and off a cliff or into a ravine and start a fire. Brain damage occurs above 107*, so those ashtray zombies who would have zero strength anyway wouldn’t be viable. I’d take an overpass, make a ramp or break out a side, dangle a disco ball and let gravity do the rest. Spears (and other polearms) > Knives - again, I get it, swords are cool and a status symbol - but they are that because only elites had swords, most footmen had spears. I don’t know why the clueless heroes on TWD don’t think of making simple spears instead of limiting themselves to arms reach with knives or why it took them 10 years to remember shields. I’m an IT guy and collect hobbies according to my guys, but I made these (all unfinished, complete ones are gone):  4x8 plywood, glue, belts, saw… I can mass produce them. Here’s where I got my inspiration. One person has a sword and OMG she’s the coolest. You can make a sword from spring steel with the right tools, which is readily available in leaf springs on trucks but better yet, cut it in thirds and make spears. You don’t have to have a blacksmith to improvise a spear, and with enough time you can fashion something made for tripping like a guisarme or bec de Corbin or lucerne hammer. To the comments: yeah, a crossbar like on a boar spear would be needed. Yes breaking through the skull is inaccurately easy in the series, but if we go with how they act in the show (not really defending themselves, just trying to eat you) then you can reasonably get to the brain through soft tissue poking up under the chin or into an eye socket. If prisoners can make these while incarcerated, why is it so hard to think of making them yourself?  Poorly reinforced fortifications - Alexandria was so amazing to the drooling mass that found it. Someone knows how to make a wall! But seriously, why weren’t the fences at the prison reinforced? Cars are everywhere and make great dead weight. Added for clarification: how do you move cars? In a pinch a couple able bodied people can push a car. I’ve done it several times. But that’s taxing and there are better ways if you apply some critical thinking. Like…  This is a M35 2.5 ton military vehicle we call a deuce and a half. It’s a workhorse. Because Mitch has a M60 Patton tank near the prison I’m certain you could find one of these. It runs on… well, anything that burns. It’s a “multi fuel engine” and likes diesel but can burn used motor oil, used vegetable oil, kerosene, gas (even bad gas) mixed with diesel, jet fuel, and even transmission or power steering fluid. What else has a multifuel engine? The Chieftain tank shown in season 1 (it was a British tank, not an M1 Abrams which is also multifuel). Another readily available fuel you can use? CNG. Compressed natural gas. Everything from big rig trucks to half tons to big and little forklifts. That’s what I was thinking of to build up the perimeter. Raid some backyard BBQs for propane. You can take the wheels off a car and set it next to the fence and suddenly no zombie herd will move it. You could line the fences all around with white crossovers and still have vehicles to spare. At any rate some form of triangulation should be used. They were there for a year and built this:  Are they out in the boonies without that much stuff to raid? Then the large herds of zombies aren’t that big a threat. So overall the biggest inaccuracy is how everyone lacks critical thinking skills.

Multiple answers here, but so far the most important point has not been adressed. All other answers deal mainly with the zombies itself, or is directly linked to them. And this is not a good way to answer, because zombies are precisely what we include in our suspension of disbelief in that show. And the question does not ask about zombies, it ask about the show. And the answer is: the most innacurate is how they have a flawed message, at its core, that human civilization is a a fragile thing that can evaporate in seconds, and we would all live in a lawlessness society, pure anarchy. This is absolutely not the case. Humans are hardcoded to live in society, it is a biological imperative ingrained in our DNA. This is how we survived and evolved. We yearn for a solid social structure. And we do make everything in our power to prevent said structure from falling apart. And the idea that almost everyone turns evil at the absence of a government is wildly exaggerated as well. A certain degree of social compromise and fairness is also written deep in our brains, as a result of millions of years of evolution surviving as a highly social animal. Even if we discount this reason, there are also practical ones: you cannot steal everything you need everytime. Sometimes, you will need something that cannot be stolen, and your life may well hang in the balance. In other words: say you and your neighbour survives the apocalipse. You can can kill him and rob his collection of cars (he was a successful mechanic and enthusiast). The cars are useful, right? But you know what would be even better? To have someone to watch your back while you sleep, and then you reciprocate. Have someone to help you if you get sick (not if, when you get sick!). Or having his expertise at handling cars instead of having the cars but no knowledge whatsoever about how to mantain them. Maybe you are a cop like Rick, and then you would provide the mechanic with safety. And maybe there is another neighbor who is a damm good cook, food is quite important isn’t it? More so in an apocalypse. And another is a nurse which can help with the many first aids that will be necessary. You get the idea: we need people, even if we were not hardcoded to it. The most inaccurate part of the Walking Dead, and indeed most zombie fiction, is a complete underestimation of the military; not only in terms of equipment and tactics, but in terms of the level of co-ordination and contingency built into modern military organisation. While it would never even get to this point, let me explain in rough terms what could easily happen assuming the general 'worst case scenario' of most zombie fiction: a complete societal breakdown where zombies outnumber humans 100:1 after the initial outbreak. While the command structure is unrecognisable, with high ranking officers largely dead, the basic rank structure of the military still holds. Get together any two soliders and they'll know exactly which one of them is in charge. Individuals attempt first to regroup with their regiments or battalions, and then simply send out messages on emergency channels to find any other military personal.Regrouping in safe, likely rural locations, is largely co-ordinated by whichever groups both held together the best, have the highest ranking officers amongst their numbers, and have the most equipment; this would likely be navy and coast guard ships that remained unaffected by the initial outbreak, as well as any military bases that were able to use their vast supplies of ammo, weapons, fortifications, and vehicles to survive what would effectively be a shitty and slow bayonet charge, something that has been easily achievable since the First World War.* This will occur in a matter of days, if not hours.Once relative order has been returned to the military structure and a basic headcount and status check has been done, there is planning into the most effective ways to evacuate civilians from urban areas so the numbers of zombies can be reduced through the deployment of carpet bombing or nuclear weapons; I imagine that for a city such as New York, this would largely involve securing key infrastructure such as bridges and tunnels using armoured vehicles, and then (assuming none already exist) setting up evacuation points in locations such as metro stations where any surviving civilians can be encouraged to make their way to. Civilians who can be trusted as assets, such as police officers and other emergency workers, will be armed and used to assist in the evacuation efforts. These evacuations will take place on the scale of weeks, perhaps months.Certain urban and semi-urban areas will be completely cleared of zombies simply by setting up firing lines and drawing them into the streets where they can be fired upon en masse with automatic weapons, before clearing buildings one at a time in small groups. These sites will be the destination for most rescued civilians, as enough infrastructure will remain for them to be supported and kept safe, fed, and sheltered. These areas will be under martial law, enforced by civilian assets and supervised by the military.As large areas become secure and order has been mostly restored, with enough food and power production to ensure stability, efforts to return to a more familiar way of life will begin. Democratic elections for leaders will return, as well construction of schools and hospitals, and attempts to reconnect with similar organisations elsewhere in the world. Occupied areas will remain divided into small, easy to secure quadrents, such that any secondary outbreak can be easily contained and eliminated, and efforts to destroy all zombies will continue to the point where the hardest part about killing zombies is finding them individually in the middle of forests and fields. Within a year or two, humans will outnumber zombies.*Fire rate of a GPMG: 650–1000 RPM; lethal radius of a grenade: 15 metres. Attack pattern of zombies: group together and walk slowly towards targets until in melee range.

Let’s take the Coronavirus pandemic as possibly the nearest thing - albeit a stretch. We think we would get a sense of whether Rick’s original gang is truthful and fair (when in fact they break many of their own rules). I think this tragic pandemic may give us some clues. It has brought out the good (amazing frontline people who have in some cases given their lives to look after others). The amazing example that comes to mind is of Don Giuseppe Berardelli, 72, an Italian archpriest. His parish rallied around and got the money to give him a potentially life-saving ventilator. He gave it to someone younger than him and died.Wow! That is humanity at is finest.I then think of the man who got drunk and deliberately went around a supermarket coughing and sneezing on people (most of whom didn’t have protective equipment). That has got to be one of the worst examples. Another that comes to mind is an article I read here in NZ about a physical altercation breaking out between two women over a pack of toilet paper (even though we have a paper mill and had heaps). In other ways, I am learning to be more loving and kind to my spouse as a practice and have found that I now value team-work and will go to great extremes to protect my family without harming anyone else. I am guessing that the good, the bad, and the in-between would come out. Anna (watched every episode of TWD and been an entertainment writer for the show).

There should be no shortage of anything that doesn’t have a shelf life. Kirkman himself said that there are 1.5 million people left alive in the entire world by the time Rick woke up. That means that most of humanity died out within 3 months. If the deaths were spread out equally among all populations, that would mean that you would have 20–30 people left alive in a city with 100,000 residents. To put that in perspective, there would be 2,600 people (or less) in total left in New York City, which currently has a population roughly in the neighborhood of 8.5 million. Atlanta - the first big city they were in - would have around 150 survivors. Washington DC would have around 215. Everything would be sitting around for the taking, including things that people had looted. After all, the looters would take things somewhere. Let’s look at guns. It is estimated that around 26% of people in Washington DC own guns. 10.3% in New York (state). 31.6% in Georgia. The national average is 29.1%. Those are just estimates based on self-reported gun ownership, and don’t reflect how many guns each respondent owned. That’s a damn lot of guns and ammo. Simply going house to house on a few streets in Georgia (where they started) would have left them armed to the teeth. Then there are gun shops, outdoor/hunting/camping stores, Wal-Marts, pawn shops, and much more. Diesel engines can be converted to run on various oils, including cooking oil. A lot of city governments in the U.S. have vehicles that run on natural gas. Then there are electric cars, various types of biofuel ones, etc. When automotive gas goes bad, there are still a ton of options. Solar and wind farms are good sources of electricity, but you can always just hit a few home supply places and get panels to hook up on your own. Electricity shouldn’t be an issue. You can get solar powered video cameras, motion-activated hunting cameras, and a lot more to insure that you always know exactly what is going on around your home, day or night. There are plenty of fortified (or easily fortified) places all over the place, including small towns. They could easily turn them into massively fortified places by using construction equipment, vehicles, etc. while the regular gas was still good. You can do a lot in 18 months. Some arduinos or raspberry pi boards, combined with solar panels and readily available add-ons (easy to find in electronics stores) could be used to make a sound-and-light based system that detects and automatically leads away herds that get too close to where you live. While the gas is still good, you could get some of the big combines and mow down vast herds of walkers. People wouldn’t be trying to kill each other if there was no scarcity. We are social creatures. There would be an overabundance of supplies in the world of TWD, so there shouldn’t be things like “All Out War.” Ultimately, once you know how walkers work, it wouldn’t be that hard to survive in the world of TWD. You could still have intense, frightening stories in that environment with some creating planning and writing, though. Better yet, if the walkers were just a little faster and/or a little more intelligent, it could still be a very dangerous place. They should have gone with “fast walkers” instead of Romero style ones.

Gunshots attracting hordes.  So many zombie movies/shows depict discharging a firearm to be suicide for all practical purposes due to the hordes being able to hear it and pinpoint your location. Have you ever heard a sound far off in the distance when you weren’t expecting it and tried to guess which direction it came from? Have you ever watched other people try to guess which direction it came from? They will look all around and some will point in the opposite direction, and even those that vaguely agree on which general area it came from will give a relatively wide degree of possible angles. Now try to guess how far off that sound was and all of the sudden you have a COLOSSAL area to search (which may or may not even include the actual origin of the sound), and this is by people that are still capable of reason, and have a memory span long enough to matter. Zombies are VERY RARELY shown to have ANY ability to reason, so they are even less likely to pinpoint your location, but even if the zombies in particular were amazing, and were capable of finding the exact location, they would become distracted on the way. Other sounds would be made (such as the footsteps of other zombies), the zombie would see/smell a “human” only to realize it is actually another zombie, or they would just flat out forget their objective and stop walking among a myriad of other possible things. That doesn’t even get touch the actual merits of a firearm over any other weapon either. Guns are going to out-range all of your other options, they have the ability to put down zombies quicker than anything else, and they reduce the risk of infection drastically. Remember how I said they had more range? Well, a bat or blade will cause blood to fly, and getting that into your eyes, mouth, cuts, or any other entrance into your body could easily spell doom without the need to ever be bitten. A bow has range too though right? Well, yes, but it is a lower range, and it requires much more strength and skill to fire a bow than a gun, not to mention the fact that you can’t carry anywhere near as many arrows as bullets, and retrieving the arrows could put you in massive danger (and they may not even come out usable). Guns would still be the most effective weapon by a large margin in a zombie infested world.

I’m going to go in the complete opposite direction of many of these answers. I’ve seen several complaining that the people haven’t built enough stuff. Many apparently think the survivors should all have full articulated plate armor along with armories stocked with the exact weapons they think are best suited to fight zombies as well as miles of ten foot deep trenches lined with spikes surrounding their settlements. This is absolutely ridiculous. The people in The Walking Dead haven’t built too little, they’ve built too much! In the first two seasons the cast was restricted to roughly a dozen people. In season three we added the community of Woodbury which had about sixty. At the end of the Woodbury ark The Governor murders his entire army which consisted of nearly all of their able bodied men and women leaving only twenty or thirty children and old men, plus Tyrese and that woman who Carol murders. One Quoran here insisted they should have reenforced the fence protecting the prison with an inner ring of cars, HOW! How do you expect about 20 able bodied people struggling to feed another 20 old men and children to push dozens of cars into place while also contending with a deadly flu outbreak? Compared to the other communities the Prison is the most realistic in terms of what can be accomplished with such limited manpower. It’s not absurd that Alexandria didn’t jackhammer their way through over a mile of road surface, utility lines and building foundations so they could supplement their wall with a trench, it’s absurd that a band of seventy suburbanites were able to build a twenty foot corrugated steel wall complete with a working gate and watch towers around their entire neighborhood with a grand total of one trained architect at their disposal and absolutely no mechanized construction equipment.   That brings us to the Hilltop. They have exactly one blacksmith, who’s near retirement and stricken with arthritis somehow churning out enough battlefield quality spears, swords, axes and arrowheads for Hilltop, The Kingdom AND the Saviors. Unlike other communities Hilltop is located in an isolated area, so they need to work extra hard to bring in materials like scrap metal. Hilltop’s wall, amazingly is made of logs.  At least Alexandria had a fresh supply of materials abandoned nearby that they could repurpose. Hilltop had to cut down hundreds of trees, lug them into place on a horse drawn cart, and line them up like a palisade, which would mean digging a foundation as well. Hilltop is no more populous than Alexandria. How did they manage to build all that with no heavy construction vehicles while also fighting off Walkers and growing crops, half of which they had to give to The Saviors? If the Walking Dead were more realistic things would be a lot more ramshackle. Alexandria’s walls would be little more than hastily thrown together barricades spanning the space between houses. A properly made metal wall should be a distant dream for them, something they could maybe MAYBE have finished by the end of the five year time-skip. The Hilltop wouldn’t have a wall, they’d have a fence at best. In fact their best bet would be to scavenge portable chain link and spread that between wooden posts. This is to say nothing of the wind-farms, irrigation systems, bio-fuel, bullet factories, bridges and other amenities they’ve built. Out of all of the groups shown The Saviors are probably the most plausible because they’re still repurposing an existing structure and rely on other communities for supplies. It’s not unrealistic that the characters in The Walking Dead haven’t built better fortifications and equipment, it’s unrealistic they could even build what they do have with such a deficit of skilled manpower.
